block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''ARABIAN NIGHTS.'' Youngsters won't have to jump aboard a magic carpet and ride to an exotic desert kingdom to hear these stories, presented by the Young Vic Theater Company. The stage action takes place on an enchanted circle of sand and features nine actors who transform themselves into maidens, rocks and goblins. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan. Tonight and Thursday night at 7; tomorrow at 1 and 7 p.m.; Sunday at noon and 6 p.m. Through Oct. 22. Tickets: $10, $20 and $25. Reservations: (212) 239-6200.

''IMAGINATION,'' a 40-minute interactive play by Elizabeth Anne Keiser in which the cast members ask the audience questions about imagination, act out ideas, portray the colors of the rainbow and play a matching game. Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 4 p.m., through Oct. 8. Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations advised. Information: (212) 307-9467.

PAPAGENO PUPPET THEATER presents two productions with Susan Delery Whedon, a puppeteer and singer: ''Hansel and Gretel,'' the fairy tale, with music by Humperdinck (at 11:30 a.m.) and ''Puff the Magic Dragon,'' with music by Peter, Paul and Mary (2:30 p.m.). Saturdays and Sundays through Oct. 29 at 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations: (212) 874-3297.

SCHMOOZY TOGETHERNESS, an hourlong musical from Manhattan Theater Source (''Kingdom of the Sun'') in which the heroine, Schmoozy, and her friends venture into a magical meta-forest. Sundays at 1 p.m. through Oct. 22 at Manhattan Theater Source, 177 MacDougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.
Events

APPLE FESTIVAL, featuring what is being called the nation's largest cobbler, baked on site with slices for sale, Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Queens County Farm Museum, 73-50 Little Neck Parkway, Queens. Activities include apple games and prizes, pressing apple cider, scarecrow making and hayrides. Free admission and parking. Information: (718) 347-3276.

DANCES BY VERY YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS. Dances for children by children. This year's students of Dance Theater Workshop, ages 7 to 16, will perform an interactive program on Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $12; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 924-0077.

''EL CIRCULO ENCANTADO/THE ENCHANTED CIRCLE.'' Fable has it that mushrooms growing in a circle are a ''fairy ring'' where elves dance and gnomes bury treasure. The artist Sylvia Benitez will make an ''enchanted ring'' of clay mushrooms on the grounds of Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Youngsters will also hear fairy stories, visit the artist's outdoor installation ''Beneath the Bark, Under Leaf and Log'' (through Oct. 30), search for growing mushrooms and make a mushroom spore print to take home. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, will present two events tomorrow for children: ''Up, Down, All Around: Sculpture,'' a guided walk through the contemporary sculpture galleries from 10 to 11 a.m., for children ages 5 to 10; ''Tours for Tots,'' from 10 to 10:45 a.m., introducing 4-year-olds to the world of art. Registration required for the latter event. Both require youngsters to be accompanied by adults. Sign-in begins at 9:45 a.m. at the museum's entrance desk. Admission: $5 per family; $3 for members. Information: (212) 708-9805.

''SCARECROW AND HARVEST WEEKEND,'' tomorrow and Sunday at the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx, will include making scarecrows, hands-on activities to celebrate the harvest, storytelling, old-fashioned hayrides, pumpkin picking and a display of scarecrows at the Everett Children's Adventure Garden. Weekend hours, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free with garden admission; various admission packages are available, including the combination ticket for access to all the grounds, $10; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $4.50 for children 2 to 12; free admission tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon. Information: (718) 817-8700.

''VOLUNTEEN CENTER,'' presented by Volunteers of America and Best Buy Company, a one-day volunteer fair for teenagers, Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. at the Central Park Rumsey Playfield, Fifth Avenue and 72nd Street. Forty nonprofit organizations from New York will be on hand (including Rock the Vote, Central Park Conservatory and the United States Fund for Unicef) to invite teenagers to sign up. Guests will include Queen Latifah, who will discuss her own dedication to volunteering, and there will be a performance by the groups R Angels and Ram-Z. Other enticements will include goodies from Dunkin' Donuts, the Gap, Street Wear and TVT Records. Free. Information: (212) 496-4346.

ANNUAL BOOK SALE, today and tomorrow, noon to 5 p.m., will include fairy tales, picture books, audiocassettes, books in other languages and fine illustrated editions. Central Children's Room of the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan. Free. Information: (212) 621-0618 or (212) 621-0636.

''PUPPETS, STORIES AND CRAFTS,'' workshops tomorrow and Sunday at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Tomorrow at 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 p.m., ''Fantastic Tales for Kids'' by the troupe Storytime Special, a Paper Puppet Presentation; from noon to 4 p.m., a mask-making workshop to create unicorns, butterflies and fairies. $2 fee with museum admission. Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., creating animal felt hand puppets out of feathers, wiggle eyes and simple stitches. $2 fee with museum admission. For all ages. Museum admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. Information: (718) 273-2060.

''STORY CORNER: MUSIC IN ART.'' A boy named Patrick who buys an old violin at a secondhand shop and transforms everything ordinary into magic will be the focus of a story told by Jessica Sack tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the fifth-floor American paintings galleries, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.
Exhibitions

''BABAR AND THE SUCCOTASH BIRD,'' an exhibition through Oct. 7 at the Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, second floor, Manhattan, featuring the first new Babar book in seven years, which is in the form of 18 original watercolors drawn by the author-illustrator, Laurent de Brunhoff. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (212) 397-0669.

THE INVENTOR CENTER, the Children's Museum of Manhattan, Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street. Recent products from the next generation of inventors: a car with helicopter blades, a mechanical glove that contains school supplies and a Duck-a-Phone, which quacks instead of rings. Featuring 10 computer workstations, the center is a high-tech idea laboratory in which children use software to realize their creations. Each hourlong workshop is limited to children 6 and older accompanied by adults. There are numerous workshops on weekends; registration is required. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; $3, the elderly; under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.

''WILLIAM WEGMAN: CANES ECCLESIORUM'' (that's Latin for church dogs), is an exhibition of the photographer's famous pooches doing amazing humanlike things, created especially for the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, through Oct. 22. Free. Information: (212) 316-7540. In a family workshop tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon, youngsters will walk through the exhibition for inspiration and afterward create animal masks out of feathers, fabric, paper and paint, then preserve the event with a Polaroid portrait of themselves. Fee: $5. Reservations: (212) 932-7347. On Sunday youngsters can wear their masks at the cathedral's annual St. Francis Day celebration, which begins at 11 a.m. with services inside and then continues throughout the day with an outdoor fair on the grounds.
